NewsLines.HeadLine: UPDATE 6-Gun battle in Indian Kashmir city on eve of vote

NewsLine.NewsLineText: KASHMIR (UPDATE 6, PICTURE):UPDATE 6-Gun battle in Indian Kashmir city on eve of vote

body.p: (Recasts with gun battle in Srinagar)
By Sanjeev Miglani and Sheikh Mushtaq

SRINAGAR, India, Sept 23 (Reuters) - A gun battle erupted between Indian security forces and suspected Islamic rebels in Kashmir's main city on Monday, the eve of the second stage in a state election racked by bloodshed.

Militants launched a string of attacks on security forces and political workers ahead of the second round of voting, which will see polling in the region's main cities Srinagar and Jammu, and the district of Budgam.

In Srinagar, one of the most heavily garrisoned cities in the world, about three gunmen fired on security forces near a polling booth just before dusk, killing one policeman, before being chased into a nearby house, police said.
Three policemen who went in after the gunmen have not been heard from since, they said. No further details were available.

About a dozen militants and soldiers were killed and several people wounded in various attacks since Sunday evening in the Himalayan state at the heart of a nine-month military standoff between nuclear-armed India and Pakistan.
Shops shut early as Srinagar, a city of 1.2 million people, prepared for the vote. Several residents said the election was no answer to the cycle of bloodshed.
"People are not involved in these elections, we need a healing touch, not elections," said Sheikh Mushtaq, a doctor.
"There is too much disillusionment. Elections are just a dodging tactic. The basic issue of Kashmir has to be addressed," said Yaqub Jan, another resident.

Rebels have threatened to kill anyone involved in the election and separatist politicians have called for a boycott, saying the vote was no substitute for a U.N.-supervised plebiscite to decide if the Muslim-majority region should be part of India or Pakistan.
Moderate separatists are not running in the election and have urged a boycott. They have also called a protest strike that is expected to shut down much of the state.
INDIA SEEKS "PROXY WAR" VICTORY

More than 35,000 people have been killed in the 13-year-revolt against Indian rule. More than 470 people, including a state minister and about 30 political workers, have been killed since the elections were called on August 2.
The first of four rounds of voting, which was largely peaceful, was held last week. The last will be on October 8.
India is hoping the vote, which is being staggered to help security forces, will strengthen its rule and weaken the revolt.
Indian Deputy Prime Minister Lal Krishna Advani said he hoped the polls would help end separatist violence.
"I look forward eagerly to this election...changing the situation even further and making it possible for India to score...victory in this proxy war," Advani said in New Delhi.
India calls the violence by the rebels in Kashmir a "proxy war" waged by Muslim Pakistan and accuses Islamabad of training and arming the guerrillas -- charges Pakistan denies.
India sees the elections as a test of Pakistan's pledge to stop militants crossing into Indian Kashmir. Pakistan rejects the poll as a farce and says infiltration by militants has stopped.
Indian authorities said turnout in the first round was a relatively strong 47 percent but separatist political leader Abdul Gani Bhat said the figure had been rigged.
Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf also dismissed the official turnout figure, saying only about 10 percent of voters, at most, went to the polls.
Thousands of extra security have been deployed ahead of Tuesday's vote. Many polling officials have been issued with bullet-proof jackets and helmets.
"Even though the threat of intimidation is unprecedented, our preparedness is also unprecedented," said state chief electoral officer Pramod Jain.

The Greater Kashmir newspaper quoted the Hizbul-Mujahideen guerrilla group as saying it had ordered attacks on polling stations. The pro-Pakistan group warned government employees and voters to stay away from polling stations.
